Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Elucidation of Dopant Effects in Ceria Supports on the Structure and Reactivity of Metal Nanoparticles
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Jing Zhou of University of Wyoming will investigate doped ceria-supported metal nanoparticles. The effect of dopants in ceria on the structure and chemistry of supported metal catalysts will be elucidated by the catalytic and surface chemistry studies of nickel and gold nanoparticles supported on a series of well-defined model ceria thin film surfaces with selected titanium and zirconium dopants using combined spectroscopy and microscopy techniques. The research will have a significant impact in the field of catalysis because it focuses on fundamental investigations of catalyst structure and reactivity at the nano-scale regime to provide the necessary foundation for the development of improved catalysts. The proposed research will also provide ample training for graduate undergraduate students in catalysis and nanoscience. Prof. Zhou will actively recruit students from underrepresented minority groups and female students to join her program.

The mechanistic understanding of nickel and gold particles supported by doped ceria can help improve steam-reforming of ethanol and CO oxidation, two very important processes in chemical industry. In addition, Prof. Jing Zhou will promote the awareness and dissemination of knowledge in nanoscience to a broad range of students and the general public through the Nanoscience Art Show and scanning tunneling microscopy demonstrations to K-12 classrooms.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focuses on the study of metal nanoparticles (e.g. Ni, Au, Co) supported on doped-ceria surfaces and aims to gain a fundamental mechanistic understanding of the effect of the dopants in ceria on the metal structure and chemistry at the atomic/molecular level. Ceria, successfully used as additives in three-way automobile emission-control catalysis, has attracted great attention in recent years in the catalysis community. Metal catalysts supported on ceria exhibit promising catalytic activity due to the unique redox properties and oxygen storage capacity of ceria. Doped ceria can provide a better catalytic support for metal catalysts for practical applications compared to pure ceria. One main issue regarding the use of pure ceria as real-world catalytic supports is its poor thermal stability at high temperatures. Doping ceria with other metal elements (e.g. Ti, Mn) forming mixed oxide supports can enhance its thermal stability, redox properties, as well as oxygen storage capacity that could lead to enhanced catalytic activity and stability of deposited metal nanoparticles.

The project successfully utilized thin film approach to engineer a series of model CeOx(111) thin films with selected Ti and Mn dopants as supports. Well-ordered CeOx(111) thin films with controlled degree of Ce reduction and atomic structures were prepared on a Ru(0001) single crystal substrate. Metal-doped ceria mixed oxide interfaces can be prepared by depositing Ti or Mn over CeOx(111) thin films. Co-deposition of Ce with metal dopants can produce well-ordered Ce1-xMxO2-d(111) (M=Ti, Mn) mixed oxide films. The role of dopants in ceria on the structure and electronic properties was examined at the atomic-scale using combined spectroscopy and microscopy techniques under ultrahigh vacuum conditions. It is demonstrated that dopant type and composition can influence the surface structures, electronic structures, and redox properties of ceria supports.

Effects of Mn and Ti dopants in ceria were investigated for metal catalysts including Ni. Ni exhibits promising chemical activity for many important catalytic reactions including steam reforming of ethanol and methane dry reforming reactions for energy production. It can effectively break the C-C and C-H bonds. However, Ni is prone to deactivation due to particle sintering and coke formation. Compared to pure ceria, addition of metal dopants in ceria can provide unique anchoring sites and interaction for deposited Ni, which can significantly stabilize Ni as small metal nanoparticles upon heating. Additionally, modified structures and electronic properties of ceria by dopants offer alternative adsorption and reaction sites and provide promotional effects in the resistance of the coke formation over deposited Ni nanoparticles in the reforming reactions.

This project integrates the proposed research into teaching, outreach activities, and establish a profound educational program in nanoscience and catalysis. The research results and infrastructure were integrated into the graduate-level special topic course (CHEM5500: Surface Science and Catalysis) that is open to both graduate students and junior/senior-level undergraduate students majoring in chemistry, physics, engineering, and geology. The project promotes the awareness of nanoscience as well as disseminate nanoscience knowledge to K-12 students through the nanoscience demo and workshops. For example, the PI and her students participated in the annual one-day Women in Science Conference held at University of Wyoming and hosted Chemistry at the Nano-world and See the Atoms workshops. Exposing female high school students to the first-hand forefront research and development in nanoscience/technology make them genuinely excited about pursuing science career paths. The project also provided opportunities to high school students for summer research. The PI sponsored three students from Laramie High School for their participation in the Wyoming Science Fair.

This grant can make a major contribution to basic catalysis and surface science, as well as applications of nanoscience and catalysis that are of importance to society. The detailed understanding of metal dopant/ceria interfaces can provide the necessary foundation for the development of improved practical ceria-based catalysts. From the educational point of view, the proposed research has had tremendous impact on educating and training of students. It provided a unique setting for the training of graduate students through extensive use of cutting-edge experimental equipment at UW and national user facilities. It excited the natural curiosity of undergraduate students, high school students, and the public about nanoscience through demonstrations, workshops, and research experience and promoted the interest of underrepresented minority groups and female students in science education.


Last Modified: 09/28/2019
Modified by: Jing Zhou
